At a news conference here in Washington yesterday, British Prime Minister Tony Blair and President Bush put on a united diplomatic front and said they would work together on Blair's ambitious program of aid, trade and debt relief for poor nations in Africa.
President Bush moved toward the idea of canceling African debt and pledged more money for famine relief, but the offer falls far short of Blair's goal.
Back in London today, the prime minister spoke perhaps a bit more candidly about the role he'd like to see the US play in what he calls a Marshall Plan for Africa.
The brutal truth is, without America in the process of dialogue and action in the international community, we aren't going to make progress on it.
Last year, Prime Minister Blair set up a commission to study the problems in Africa and come up with recommendations.
Rock singer Bob Geldof is among the members.
The musician and activist recently announced plans for a group of concerts to be held on July 2nd in five countries to focus attention on Africa.
And this of course is not his first effort in this regard.
Twenty years ago, Geldof was the principal organizer of the Live Aid concerts which raised over a hundred million dollars.
He calls next month's concerts Live 8 because they're scheduled just days before the leaders of the leading industrialized countries meet at the G8 Summit at Gleneagles in Scotland.
